ns0:coredata.dc:title: Advanced energy technologies, methods, and policies to support the sustainable development of energy, water and environment systems
ns0:coredata.dc:creator: Buonomano, Annamaria
Barone, Giovanni
Forzano, Cesare
ns0:coredata.dc:description: This editorial discusses the contributions of the papers belonging to the virtual special issue (VSI) of Energy Reports dedicated to the series of four SDEWES Conferences on Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems held in Cologne (Germany), Sarajevo (Bosnia and Herzegovina), Gold Coast (Australia) and Buenos Aires (Argentina) in 2020. High quality review papers and original research articles presented at the SDEWES Conferences relevant to the Journal are included in this VSI for a total of 20 accepted articles invited by the Guest Editors. Published papers deal with key research topic related to clean energies, advance energy technologies, building-plant design solutions, energy management measures, policies and regulations capable to ensure that all countries and regions develop and implement expertise and technologies to tackle climate change and make progress towards a net zero energy economy. Such a complex goal poses some major challenges and calls for the effort of scientists and stakeholders to commit to develop and carry out multidisciplinary approaches towards the sustainable development of modern cities for a decarbonized economy. This process is also crucial for achieving a successful and just energy transition, necessary to reduce sources of conflict and iniquity typical of geopolitical tensions, to avoid causes of uncertainty in the long run to the sustainable development Agenda, towards energy security, environmental protection, and the affordability of energy. In this framework, the Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems Series Conference represents a platform for the development of inter-sectoral collaborations among scientists and stakeholders and it promotes the development and improvements of advanced energy technologies and systems for the sustainable and just transition. The SDEWES Conferences brought together around 1000 researchers from all over the world working in the field of the sustainable development. According to the papers published in the VSI of Energy Reports dedicated to SDEWES Conferences, the editorial is subdivided in several sections based on the relevant topics on which the VSI papers are focused: renewable technologies for the energy efficiency of buildings and communities, advanced technologies and tools for the energy efficient design of buildings and systems, challenges and opportunities of policies and regulations to support the energy transition and meet the sustainable development targets.

ns7:abstract-sec.ns7:simple-para: This editorial discusses the contributions of the papers belonging to the virtual special issue (VSI) of Energy Reports dedicated to the series of four SDEWES Conferences on Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems held in Cologne (Germany), Sarajevo (Bosnia and Herzegovina), Gold Coast (Australia) and Buenos Aires (Argentina) in 2020. High quality review papers and original research articles presented at the SDEWES Conferences relevant to the Journal are included in this VSI for a total of 20 accepted articles invited by the Guest Editors. Published papers deal with key research topic related to clean energies, advance energy technologies, building-plant design solutions, energy management measures, policies and regulations capable to ensure that all countries and regions develop and implement expertise and technologies to tackle climate change and make progress towards a net zero energy economy. Such a complex goal poses some major challenges and calls for the effort of scientists and stakeholders to commit to develop and carry out multidisciplinary approaches towards the sustainable development of modern cities for a decarbonized economy. This process is also crucial for achieving a successful and just energy transition, necessary to reduce sources of conflict and iniquity typical of geopolitical tensions, to avoid causes of uncertainty in the long run to the sustainable development Agenda, towards energy security, environmental protection, and the affordability of energy.

In this framework, the Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems Series Conference represents a platform for the development of inter-sectoral collaborations among scientists and stakeholders and it promotes the development and improvements of advanced energy technologies and systems for the sustainable and just transition. The SDEWES Conferences brought together around 1000 researchers from all over the world working in the field of the sustainable development. According to the papers published in the VSI of Energy Reports dedicated to SDEWES Conferences, the editorial is subdivided in several sections based on the relevant topics on which the VSI papers are focused: renewable technologies for the energy efficiency of buildings and communities, advanced technologies and tools for the energy efficient design of buildings and systems, challenges and opportunities of policies and regulations to support the energy transition and meet the sustainable development targets.

ns7:keyword.ns7:text: Fifth-Generation bidirectional low temperature District Heating and Cooling
Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems
Policies and regulatios of energy markets

ns7:section.ns7:para: This virtual special issue (VSI) of Energy Reports (EGYR) is dedicated to the series of SDEWES Conferences on Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems held in Cologne (Germany, September 1–5), Sarajevo (Bosnia and Herzegovina, June 28–July 2), Gold Coast (Australia, April 6–9) and Buenos Aires (Argentina, February 9–12) in 2020. The article collection of Energy Reports is dedicated to four SDEWES 2020 Conferences attended by a high number of researchers and scientists from more than 60 countries that presented about 700 papers focused on a wide range of research topics linked to the fields of energy, water and environment. This is the first VSI of EGYR dedicated to the SDEWES Conferences and it includes 20 accepted papers from the SDEWES 2020 Conferences that met the high-quality criteria of the Journal and cover a wide variety of issues including clean energies, advance energy technologies, building-plant design solutions, energy management measures, policies and regulations, and advanced energy technologies and systems for the sustainable energy transition. The 20 published papers, that will be presented in detail, propose novel approaches and remarkable advances in recognized research lines explored also in previous SDEWES Conferences. This article collection follows the path of many special issues of recognized Journals dedicated to the SDEWES Conferences, such as the VSIs of SDEWES 2018 (Piacentino et al., 2020; Kılkış et al., 2019; Østergaard et al., 2020b), 2019 (Gjorgievski et al., 2021; Østergaard et al., 2020a; Kılkış et al., 2020; Vujanović et al., 2021), 2020 (Guzović et al., 2022; Nastasi et al., 2022; Mikulčić et al., 2021). In this regard, it is worth noticing that the SDEWES Conferences have continuously expanded in the last two decades, the number of participants and submitted research papers have increased over the year and with them the number of covered topics, becoming one of the most relevant international conferences in the field.

Discussed studies of this VSI, hereinafter cited by authors’ names differently from the other cited papers, are mostly dedicated to renewable energy systems and applications, as well as to models, simulations, and optimization procedures towards the achievement of the zero-energy target at a local, regional and national levels, and to the implementation of proper policies and regulations with a focus on the energy markets and their impact on the sustainable and just energy transition.

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Energy efficiency in buildings: methodologies and tools
ns7:section.ns7:para: To achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, energy efficiency and demand reduction are crucial to ensure flexibility in the selection of the available decarbonization options, avoiding social and environmental side effects. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), the building sector is responsible for 36% of global final energy consumption and 40% of total direct and indirect CO2 emissions (Agency, 2020). Additionally, the energy demand of the building sector is still growing due to the increased access to energy in developing countries and to increasing quality of life (Agency, 2020). Therefore, aiming at the sustainable development of the modern economy, to reduce the energy and environmental impact of the building sector, an impressive effort has been done worldwide by researchers and governments to promote the use of energy-efficient design and technologies towards the target of the nearly zero energy building (nZEB) (López-Ochoa et al., 2019). Achieving the zero-energy target in buildings requires the implementation of suitable design measures, Renewable energy sources (RES) based technologies, and advanced energy saving devices/strategies.

The available literature shows a more and more increasing number of papers and reviews about technologies, measures, and strategies to be adopted for reducing the energy demand of the building sector (Gatt et al., 2020). Although the significant and high- quality research conducted by researchers, there is still the need of more effort to achieve the nZEB goal (Wu and Skye, 2021). With the aim at achieving a balance between building energy needs and renewable energies supply, it is thus necessary to perform the passive design of the building envelope for the reduction of energy demands and loads, and to implement innovative and renewable energy technologies (Ferrara et al., 2021). To achieve the minimization of the energy needs and the maximization of energy supply, the design and implementation of energy efficient building-plant systems has been more and more investigated by the use of dynamic energy simulation models and optimization procedures, generally applied to case study analyses (Tang et al., 2020; Buonomano et al., 2016). In this framework, Tootkaboni et al. (2021) propose a study based on the investigation of the impact of climate changes on the heating and cooling energy demand, and of the overall energy performance and overheating risk of typical residential buildings located in Milan (Italy). The paper aims to provide design guidelines for the design of the next generation of buildings by drawing a picture of the future performance of Italian residential buildings until the end of the 21st century. The study offers insights into the climate resiliency of Italian residential building stocks, fulfilling a literature gap at a regional and national level. To perform the study, the authors calculated the overall energy performance of three building types with heating and cooling systems with continuous operation, by also considering the overheating risk in free floating regime. The three buildings are representative of the existing Italian residential building stock, under different future scenarios and by considering different insulation and refurbishment levels. Dynamic simulations are conducted by means of Energy Plus simulation engine, whereas future weather data are obtained by the WeatherShift TM tool. The authors found out that for the investigated buildings, a radical rise in cooling energy use and a slight decrease in heating energy use are expected, together with the increase of the overheating risk for existing buildings (higher discomfort hours) up to 30%. The study highlights the need to consider climate change for re-identifying refurbishment actions, whereas the authors underline the urgent need of regional and localized analysis to establish building adaptation measures for climate change (Tootkaboni et al., 2021).

To enhance the passive design of buildings to improve their energy efficiency towards the zero-energy goal, Hammad et al. (2021) propose a methodology based on a mixed integer non-linear programming (MINLP) approach for the selection of building materials and construction building systems. The authors propose a mathematical programming framework aimed at the optimization of several objective functions related to design parameters of buildings influencing heat gains, daylight and economic cost of building materials (a database consisting of more than 250 materials and construction building systems is used). To conduct the analysis, a building information model (BIM) of the project is generated, necessary to evaluate building components geometries and to manage their data, used to feed a building energy modelling (BEM) simulation tool. In addition, the authors developed a multi-objective MINLP approach to optimize the building project from the energy perspective. To this aim, two realistic case studies relative to a house and a commercial building, both located in the humid subtropical climate of Sydney (Australia) are considered; quantitative results on the daylight (＋11%), heat gain (−34%), and cost (＋23%) of the simulated buildings are achieved. The authors propose such a methodology for decision-making aims, providing guidelines for the building sector stakeholders dealing with the material choice and window sizing to achieve energy-efficient and economical buildings (Hammad et al., 2021). The BIM approach has been used to overcome the issue of interoperability, promoting the collaboration among diverse skills and competences to the sustainable and effective design of buildings. The BIM to BEM methodology has gained a lot of interest among the research community, as observed by the amount of research papers published on this topic in the recent years (Barone et al., 2021b). Concerning this, Sušnik et al. (2021) exploit the available software to perform energy and acoustic analyses through BIM-based simulation environments with the aim at highlighting their benefits and drawbacks to provide a guide for users dealing with interoperability issues.

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Sustainable development of smart cities and communities
ns7:section.ns7:para: To tackle climate change and reach net zero emissions in the coming decades, the development of zero-energy buildings and the spread of renewable energy technologies have led to the concepts of self-sustaining and energy-independent communities (Thellufsen et al., 2020). Buildings have been changing from being just energy consumers to energy prosumers (i.e. producers plus consumers) and, as a consequence, the nearly-zero principles are now applied to communities (Guo et al., 2022). To reach the nearly zero energy community (nZEC) target, a crucial role is played by RES as well as by the control and the optimization of energy flows within the community (Kılkış, 2021). Concerning this, the recent research trend highlights the continuous progress and design of suitable energy schemes for the sustainable development of smart cities and communities (Piselli et al., 2021). According to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 (Nilsson et al., 2016), this goal includes crucial and multi-disciplinary targets, among others it is worth highlighting: inclusive and sustainable urbanization to be achieved through intelligent urban planning; sustainable transport including infrastructure, public transport systems, and goods delivery networks; protection of natural and cultural heritage; reduction of the adverse impact of natural disasters to make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable (Sun et al., 2022; Wang et al., 2021; Mimica and Krajačić, 2021). In this regard, to foster the development of safe and reliable and cost-effective RES, and the achievement of sustainable targets by providing more accurate predictions and forecasts of energy generation and demand (Onile et al., 2021), innovative techniques based on machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) approaches are being developed (Zahraee et al., 2016; Hannan et al., 2021).

Technologies required for cutting energy demands and for enabling the integration of local and distributed RES are nowadays well known and have reached market maturity (Sebestyén and Abonyi, 2021). Thus, it is necessary to provide all stakeholders with the adequate tools for decision making aims also capable to deal with novel energy management schemes (Buonomano, 2020). These tools also include case study analyses to be internationally recognized as best practice examples, conducted to provide insights to effectively support the energy transition by overcoming several barriers such as government support, population cooperation, and future vision (Barone et al., 2021; Nezhad et al., 2021).

In this framework, Maturo et al. (2021) propose a research work to contribute to the knowledge of the potentials and issues related to the design of energy independent communities, by proposing energy schemes to be potentially applied to agricultural and zootechnical communities. They involve integrated energy efficiency technologies and novel system layouts aiming at reaching the nZEC goal, by also considering collective energy actions with provision of benefits for members and stakeholders. The proposed methodology includes dynamic simulation and optimization analyses based on energy and economic objective functions to identify the optimal integration of energy efficient systems for diverse configuration scenarios. A case study analysis focused on an existing agricultural and zootechnical community located nearby the continental climate city of Turin (Italy).

The investigated technologies are a gas fuelled co-generator and an anaerobic biodigester, solar based collectors, smart mobility, district heating and cooling, simulated in diverse configuration scenarios (Askeland et al., 2019). The use of an anaerobic digester fed by agricultural waste leads to promising energy and economic savings (＋25%), reaching +70% in case of a solar assisted district cooling system.

To support the electrification of energy and use with regard of space heating and cooling in smart communities can be accomplished also by electrically-driven primary heating and cooling equipment that can benefit from waste heat (von Rhein et al., 2019; Allen et al., 2020). This is the case of low temperature district heating and cooling networks, often modelled by complex mathematical models capable to simulate the energy performance of diverse network topologies (Barone et al., 2020b). The investigation of an innovative fifth-generation bidirectional low temperature district heating and cooling (5GDHC) network to achieve a nearly zero energy district (nZED) is presented by Bilardo et al. (2021). To this aim, the authors modelled a 5GDHC network based on water source heat pumps, as well as on-site renewable sources and waste energy recovery. The developed model allows assessing the energy performance of 5GDHC networks through simulations, providing a pre-design tool useful for carrying out preliminary assessment of similar networks. From a case study analysis based on 11 real users with different needs located in USA climates, interesting outcomes in terms of energy savings (＋35%) are achieved. The findings of this research highlight how the integration of established technologies into 5GDHC networks is effective towards the nZED goal.

A simplified methodology to assess the economic feasibility of a micro-wind turbine at urban level is proposed by Pellegrini et al. (2021) with the aim to promote the implementation of this technology. The authors present the result of an extensive experimental analysis of a micro-wind turbine installed in Forlì (Italy), providing real energy performance. Monitoring data are analysed by the authors to propose a simplified approach for the estimation of the energy and economic performance of similar installations based on local wind conditions. Along with the tool to predict the potential of local wind resource, the authors provide recommendations to enhance the energy and economic performance of the micro-wind turbine with the aim to boost their competitiveness to further promote the centralized generation of energy at district and community level.

As previously mentioned, the sustainable development of smart cities and communities also includes the reduction of the impact of water related disasters to prevent the degradation of the urban environment and the impoverishment of the population. Floods represent a challenge to cities with long-term effects often neglected. In this regard, the research paper proposed by Guimarães et al. (2021) aims at expanding the concept of cascading effects in the flood assessment context, to consider the consequences of successive flooding events over a time horizon. The authors propose a modelling approach, that complements other tools by introducing social vulnerability, to assess the watershed recovery deficit considering a sequence of flood events, also considering previous events, overcoming the single spatial analysis approach. The proposed method is applied to the Acari River watershed, located in the city of Rio de Janeiro (Brazil), for which the improvement in the recovery capacity of the watershed’s population is measured quantitatively by the recovery deficit index (＋31%).

Finally, transport has a key role in the sustainable development allowing for a cleaner environment, social equity, as well as health, resilience of cities and linkages and productivity of rural areas (Barone et al., 2020a). The sustainable transport target also includes infrastructures which call for more stringent requirements on the maintenance of roads and streets to ensure traffic safety. Road maintenance technology refer to the preservation of asphalt concrete pavement, the higher its quality the better the adhesion of the wheel to the roadway for safety. Different techniques are available for the road maintenance, a chemical treatment as impregnating composition protects the surface of asphalt concrete roads from impacts, being an effective solution to provide hydroprotection. Concerning road impregnations to improve safety of roads, Bessarabov et al. (2021) developed a computer-aided tool for quality management system of impregnating compositions for road asphalt concrete pavements based on the life cycle concept. The authors provide computer support and info about technological regulations in the framework of the chemical products for road impregnation.

To accelerate the clean energy transition, it is mandatory to cut down the energy consumptions of transportation sectors, which is responsible for a quarter of the global energy consumption and of worldwide greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The maritime transportation sector is responsible for 3.3% of CO2 emissions, however it is expected to growth in term of energy demand (Barone et al., 2021a, 2020d). Severe restrictions and measures for the reduction of the GHG emissions of ships and vessels have been imposed by the International Maritime Organization, including the adoption of new technologies and strategies to enhance the ships energy efficiency (Halff et al., 2019; Zhen et al., 2018). Among the available actions and strategies for reducing naval polluting emissions there are: optimization of ship sailing routes and speed (Vettor and Guedes Soares, 2016), enhancement of the efficiency of ship components and adoption of novel energy system technologies (Tse et al., 2011). The reduction of sailing speed (slow steaming) is considered as a short-term operational measure for reducing GHG emissions from ships at sea (Dong and Tae-Woo Lee, 2020). The impact of slow steaming on fuel consumption and CO2 emissions is analysed by Degiuli et al. (2021) by using the example of a container ship on a typical sailing route passing through the Mediterranean Sea. The considered ship is fuelled by low sulphur marine gas oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG). The authors found out that through the slow steaming approach, significant economic and environmental benefits can be achieved: for a speed reduction of 13.6%, up to 31% and 49% of savings in fuel oil consumption and CO2 emissions are obtained with engines powered by low sulphur marine gas oil and by natural gas, respectively.

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Energy mix, cleaner fuels and innovative technologies for the sustainable transition
ns7:section.ns7:para: Smart grids, mini or micro, includes distributed energy systems from RES and traditional fuels, which can be operated in island mode or connected to a main electrical grid (Heydari et al., 2020). The development of smart grids is strictly linked to the spread of distributed energy systems (DES) and the identification of the optimal energy mix is a technical and economic concern (Kim et al., 2020; Obi et al., 2020). Moreover, the development of management and control techniques for the proper design and integration of different energy resources is an open problem for the sustainable deployment of DES (Zia et al., 2018). Examples are available in the literature; here, many case study analyses have been developed and proposed as benchmark studies for supporting the development of design and operation guidelines. To this aim, great efforts have been devoted to the investigation of self-sustaining and energy-independent communities of small and off-grid islands, which are suitable to suit pilot projects of self-sufficient energy communities (Barone et al., 2021c; Prina et al., 2021; Groppi et al., 2021).

A particular focus on the potential of renewable energy sources for electricity production in Serbia is proposed by Pavlović et al. (2021). The investigation is conducted through a multi-criteria decision-making approach to optimize the renewable energy alternatives for electricity generation. The authors highlight that in the Serbian energy mix, the current share of RES utilization is not adequate; however, the two alternatives, hydropower and biomass, are identified as almost equally promising for a sustainable increase in the share of renewables in electricity generation and enabling a continuity in energy supply for the national development.

The use of multi-objective optimization procedure and energy management algorithms to increase the penetration of DES in the power generation grid has also been widely investigated (Fuster-Palop et al., 2021; Hassan et al., 2020). Nicolosi et al. (2021) propose a novel mixed integer linear programming (MILP) optimization algorithm to aid the design of a micro-grid consisting of internal combustion generators and a micro gas turbine, considering different fuelling options, including renewable fuels. The authors aim at providing a flexible optimization algorithm developed in Python, including special features often neglected in the literature, such as the effects of start-ups and shutdowns. The considered load profile has been depicted by measurement data from a village located in the Penserjoch mountain pass of the Italian region of South Tyrol. Through the research, the authors demonstrate the significance to build up optimization tools to control advanced energy systems and mix of technologies and fuels to improve the micro-grid performance.

The use of alternative fuels to replace fossil fuels has been investigated by several authors to achieve energy security and protect the environment, although concerns about the indirect greenhouse gas emissions from their production and consumption, such as land-use exploitation, carbon leakage, and biomass transportation (Stančin et al., 2020; Bidir et al., 2021). Biofuels are strong candidates to these goals; they refer to liquid or gaseous fuel mainly produced from biomass, such as methanol, ethanol, biodiesel, and gaseous fuels, such as hydrogen and methane (Bedoić et al., 2020; Seljak et al., 2020). Their suitability has been tested over the diesel behaviour, however there is still research to do to evaluate their potential capability in real-time applications (Knápek et al., 2021; Pour and Makkawi, 2021). In general, the engine output characteristics for the biofuels can be improved by adopting various techniques such as fuel reformulation, optimize the engine design parameter, calibration of control parameters and after-treatment devices (Vignesh and Ashok, 2021; Nguyen and Gustavsson, 2020). In this framework, Ayad et al. (2021) propose a novel virtual engine calibration method for alternative fuels such as ethanol, hydrogen, and natural gas, by using thermodynamic simulation for in-cylinder pressure prediction. The optimization model, developed by considering engine data, considers as decision variables combustion and heat transfer model parameters. The authors, thanks to the multi-objective optimization method combined with a proper engine map, resulted to be useful in engine development and optimization for different fuels and operating conditions. The research contributes to provide knowledge on the use of alternative fuels, reducing the need of experimental investigations, and providing guidelines for future engine research (Ayad et al., 2021). The conversion of biomass into gas suitable for energy exploitation is interesting topic that gained increasing attention within the research community (Aste et al., 2020), also considering their favourable management and production costs (Hussain et al., 2017). As before reported, the energy stored in biomass can be converted into biosolid (Wzorek and Tanczuk, 2015), bio-oil (Silva et al., 2016) and biogas (Eggemann et al., 2020) fuels or directly co-firing with conventional fuels such as coal (Kazagic et al., 2016; Pfeifer et al., 2020). The use of biogas to fuel a natural gas engine coupled to an organic rankine cycle (ORC) was proposed by Klun et al. (2021) with the aim at evaluating the possibility of generating electricity by recovering the engine exhaust heat and converting it to electricity (Anastasovski et al., 2020). Conversion of biomass into gas for further exploitation is viable green solution due to the availability of raw materials. Among the available processes, gasification allows a partial combustion of biomass in a reduced oxygen environment to produce hydrogen-enriched syngas, suitable for further energy conversions, especially for the use in gas turbines, fuel cells and internal combustion engines (Cavaignac et al., 2021; Mancusi et al., 2021). Higher hydrogen yield can be produced in updraft gasifier if compared to other designs. Concerning this topic, Cerinski et al. (2021) propose a new model approach for the bottom-lit updraft gasification process using a combination of a kinetic mechanism with a thermodynamic equilibrium model, to be used for further development. Simulation data are compared to experimental ones for three cases of air gasification and eight cases for air and steam gasification, showing a general good agreement between measures and predictions, for both hydrogen and carbon monoxide estimation, with an average prediction error below 10%. Concerning the reduction of the environmental impact of coal-fired power plants, Nunes Rodrigues et al. (Rodrigues et al., 2021) propose a quantitative study on the oxidation kinetics of semi-dry flue-gas desulphurization (R-FGD) with hot air in a cost effective fluidized bed reactor pilot plant through an experiment design. The results of the research show that the predicted sulphite conversion optimized profiles exhibit reasonable adherence with predicted conversions on the experimental points.

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Solar based technologies for the building integration
ns7:section.ns7:para: Among the available technologies based on RES, photovoltaic (PV) systems are the most widely exploited, for both building and industrial applications. To increase the efficiency of PV systems, the hybrid technology of Photovoltaic Thermal (PV/T) systems have gained an increasing attention in the last years, due to the simultaneous production of heat and electricity (Fouas et al., 2020; Ocłoń et al., 2020). In fact, instead of installing two separate solar collectors (i.e. a solar thermal collector and a photovoltaic module (Kalogirou et al., 2019; Visa et al., 2019)), generating electricity and heat with one device increases the overall energy utilization and power density for flat plate and concentrating devices (Barone et al., 2022a; Novelli et al., 2021). In fact, a photovoltaic/thermal hybrid (PV/T) device consists of a thermal collector with an absorber made of PV that produces electricity whereas the thermal energy is transported away by a working fluid, generally water and air. The research on PV/T systems has been increasing in the last years, different kind of PV/T systems have been developed, including different geometries and shapes of the absorber (Barone et al., 2020c; Kotkondawar et al., 2021) and of the heat exchanger (Barone et al., 2019c), different coatings (Huang et al., 2022b), diverse working fluids, standard (water, air, bifluids) and innovative (nanofluids) (Cui et al., 2021), etc. The use of phase change materials integrated within the PV/T have been also studied to control the PV temperature and increase its efficiency (Buonomano and Guarino, 2020; Ali and Mustafa, 2020; Cui et al., 2022). At the same time, possible hybrid applications, residential and industrial, have been proposed and investigated (Herrando et al., 2019; Barone et al., 2019a).

The paper proposed by Barbu et al. (2021) focuses on an innovative configuration of a PV/T panel consisting of a water-based roll-bond collector with mono-crystalline silicon PV cells, analysed by means of an explicit dynamic numerical model developed by the authors. The research work aims at evaluating the system performance through the calculation of energy and economic indicators, evaluated for various operational and design parameters. To this aim, a parametric analysis is applied to the proposed PV/T panel as a function of diverse climate conditions relative to European Continental cities, Strasbourg (France) and Bucharest (Romania). The proposed and modelled device refers to a liquid-based (30/70% glycol–water mix) PV/T collector with a direct flow geometry of the collector and roll bond channels. The roll bond fabrication method of the collector is relatively cheap and allows to improve the system economic feasibility. The mathematical model based on heat transfer and power balances is successfully validated by comparing the performance results to experimental data found in the literature, considering the same configuration and operating conditions used in the experiment. Additionally, the authors propose a comprehensive parametric analysis conducted by varying several parameters, one factor at a time, such as wind speed, packing factor of the PV cell, thickness of insulation, and width of tube (Barbu et al., 2021). Through such analysis, some technical recommendations for the efficient operation of the proposed PV/T collector are formulated; the PV/T was also simulated in diverse configurations. First, the roof installation allows a better wind protection with benefits in terms of energy efficiency also due to the lower amount of dust collected and the low maintenance cost. The insulation is crucial to improve thermal efficiency, however the thicker the insulation the higher the installation cost, as well as the bulkiness and weight of the equipment; therefore, a technical solution requires the use of alternative materials with lower coefficient of thermal loss. The proposed packing factor for the PV layer depends on the application since thermally driven and electrically driven require diverse configurations. Depending on the energy market prices, it might be beneficial to choose a high packing factor for the PV/T design (the electrical energy is more valuable from the energy and economic points of view, although a high packing factor typically involves increased costs of the PV cells. Finally, the width of the channels influences the pumping power; however, due to technical constrains on the fabrication methods of roll bond absorbers, the width of the tube is limited to 8–10 mm depending on the manufacturing method, materials and distance between the channels.

Among the possible and interesting applications of PV/T devices, their integration in the building has gained an increasing attention, being a promising technology to balance the household electricity and thermal consumption (Barone et al., 2019b). They can be applied or integrated to different components of buildings, such as floors, walls, and double skin façades (Ioannidis et al., 2017; Athienitis et al., 2018). Building integrated PV/T systems (known as BIPV/T) have been investigates from diverse aspects, analysing their energy and indoor comfort performance, economic feasibility and benefits, as well as architectural and aesthetic characteristic (Vassiliades et al., 2022; Rounis et al., 2021).

BIPV/T are more and more studied to understand their optimal system configurations, including their operation as a function of the design and of the cooling fluid, also towards the achievement of the zero-energy target at a building and district level (Cillari et al., 2021). In this framework, the paper presented by Theokli et al. (2021) aims to investigate the importance of refurbishing old buildings rather than demolishing them to improve energy efficiency by implementing innovative façade systems. The study is conducted in a Mediterranean climate by means of a case study analysis based on the integration of active solar energy systems on double building facades. Along with the active performance, the passive contribution of the double façade on the energy and indoor comfort performance are also investigated. The authors aim at proposing a methodology of an interdisciplinary approach for the design of the proposed renewable applications in similar climatic conditions. The main results of the study, conducted by a 3D simulation tool, regard the qualitative and quantitative efficacy of the energy renovation of an existing building located in Nicosia (Cyprus) by using BIPV/T panels integrated in a corridor type double façade system, towards the achievement of the nZEB goal in the eastern-southern European climate zone (Theokli et al., 2021). Simulation results proved that building refurbished by the solar active double façade allows covering the Cyprus’ nZEB standards in terms of energy consumption and production, with more than 25% of the building total primary energy consumption (123 kWh/m2 per year) is produced in-situ by BIPV/T.

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Policies and regulations of energy markets: challenges and opportunities
ns7:section.ns7:para: With the aim at achieving a sustainable and just energy transition, several challenges must be addressed to prevent energy poverty and associated impacts, including social iniquity. The Covid-19 pandemic and international conflicts enormously impacted on the financial side of the energy market, limiting investments and threatening to slow the spread of key clean energy technologies and the implementation of sustainable measures (Kuzemko et al., 2020; Su et al., 2021). Nevertheless, these crises represent both challenges and opportunities to boost the sustainable and just transition to meet the stringent goals of the Paris Agreement and, at the same time, to reduce the impact of geopolitical tensions on energy market, economy growth and social development (Bashir et al., 2022). In this regard, researchers and scientists are called to provide clear recommendations on how governments can put energy and sustainability issues at the heart of incentive plans by setting-up proper policies and regulations also necessary to create jobs and build more modern, resilient and clean energy systems (Hrnčić et al., 2021).

The increasing share of distributed energy resources, especially those based on RES for the reduction of the energy consumption of cities and communities before mentioned, require the deployment of advanced energy markets capable to keep the power grid balanced (Zsiborács et al., 2021). The unsynchronous power generation and consumption needs complete adjustments within an acceptable timeframe to balance the frequency disturbances on the grid and power outages (Al-Hinai et al., 2021). Since the production of power by RES implies the fluctuations in the supply and demand of energy causing grid instability, to tackle this issue system operators are developing techniques and technologies to ensure the effective adaptation of renewable energy in smart grids with the support of energy storage systems (ESS) (Al kez et al., 2020; Roselli et al., 2020). At the same time, part of the solution is to foster the deployment and implementation of innovative business models and coordination schemes also necessary to reduce the costs of frequency support services from grid operators (Xue et al., 2022).

In this regard, local energy markets also play a crucial role towards the grid balance. Advanced frameworks for the assessment of local energy balancing with the goal of reducing the peak load on increasingly congested electrical grids and to reward participants have been more and more established. In fact, market programmes for local energy exchange, involving peer-to-peer trading (Wu et al., 2022), restricted to a single region or a community depending on grid constraints (Huang et al., 2022a), are more and more developed and tested. Their objective is to enable increased local production, typically from RES, and lower the stress on the transmission and distribution grids, especially during peak time to prevent or reduce congestions by incentivizing self-consumption (Fichera et al., 2020), using local flexibility from production (O’Connell et al., 2021), generation and storage (Manfren et al., 2021). Researchers and organizations working in this field are developing technical and supervisory solutions to enhance the RES deployment for electricity generation (Derasid et al., 2021), including smart home appliances to increase or add flexibility (Kirkerud et al., 2021; Wesseh and Lin, 2022), mobile and stationary storages (Van Kriekinge et al., 2021; Barone et al., 2022b), and energy management schemes (Mimica et al., 2021), suggesting policy and regulatory strategies, including demand response techniques (Kanakadhurga and Prabaharan, 2021). The available literature also shows an increasing number of research works on the development of energy schemes towards the maximization of self-consumption of electricity from RES and on simulative frameworks for a multi-regional assessment of local energy markets (Zhao et al., 2022).

In this context, a comprehensive review of the current state and planned developments in the electricity sectors across several countries in South East Europe is presented by Borozan et al. (2021). The authors aim at providing a benchmark analysis for further investigation of the SEE region, highlighting challenges in implementing the EU energy policy requirements. The review focuses on several topics: implementation of required legislation, electricity market development, and integration of RES, emerging technologies, and smart concepts, with the aim at underlining barriers to efficient market operation and proposing potential solutions in a regional context towards the definition of potential directions in regional development in response to the latest challenges in electricity market design for a low-carbon future. The investigation was further conducted in close cooperation with the transmission system operators of the investigated SEE countries, facing many challenges in the development of the wholesale electricity and balancing markets, as also discussed by Krstevski et al. (2021). As the research includes countries that are both EU Member States and West Baltic countries in the process of accession to EU, the work represents reference on the path towards the implementation of a regional balancing market.

As for the electricity market, the proper balance among gas consumption, reserved gas quantities and transmission system capacities, has a key aspect for the natural gas market influencing the quantity of the balancing energy needed (Sutrisno and Alkemade, 2020). It is worth noticing that natural gas is an essential fuel source in developed countries, responsible for about 25% of the world gross energy consumption (Fetisov et al., 2021). Natural gas is expected to keep playing a crucial role in the next decades, especially during the sustainable energy transition being a backup fuel for intermittent RES (Samseth, 2013) and due to its relatively low environmental impact, particularly for electric power generation. Natural gas has surpassed coal as the number two energy source and has potentials to overtake oil’s share in many industrialized economies due to falling costs for transporting gas, by pipeline and by ship as liquefied natural gas (Serrato et al., 2021). The increase of gas importation in modern economies, particularly in Europe and North America, along with its rapidly growing significance in geopolitics, are forcing the development of new measures towards energy security and the reduction of the dependence on foreign supplies (Anon, 2006; Bilgin, 2011). In this matter, the liberalization of natural gas market can be considered as adequate with respect to energy security and efficient allocation of scarce resources in the short run (Radetzki, 1999). On the other hand, major structural and institutional conditions, also linked to geopolitics and market power of suppliers countries, often reduce the efficiency of the gas market in the long run (Bilgin, 2009). On this subject, the market power of suppliers and transit countries is an important structural element of the natural gas market, considering that few countries possess the majority of current proved gas reserves (Eser et al., 2019; Sauvageot, 2020). Thus, to achieve long-term investment and contracts consistent forecasts of natural gas demand are advisable as demonstrated by the literature, that shows an increasing number of papers on this topic (Liu et al., 2021a,b). Although the complexity of the natural gas market, reliable demand forecasts become more and more crucial to support the whole market (Dilaver et al., 2014; Wei et al., 2022) as reviewed by Smajla et al. (2021). The authors investigate the impact of forecast methods as balancing operations performed by the system operators to adjust the quantity of gas delivered to and from the transport system and to reduce the risk of financial losses due to higher price of natural gas balance. To this aim, accurate forecasts of natural gas consumption are considered necessary to ensure small deviations among actual gas consumption, reserved gas volumes and transmission system capacity. The authors also provide a methodology for analysing the optimal number of smart meters necessary to reach satisfactory accuracy in forecasting natural gas consumption by using simple forecasting methods as an alternative to complex machine learning methods. Based on conducted research, natural gas consumption and temperature were suggested as parameters to be used for forecasting natural gas demand.

This Virtual Special Issue of Energy Reports is dedicated to the series of four Conferences on Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systems held in Cologne (Germany), Sarajevo (Bosnia and Herzegovina), Gold Coast (Australia) and Buenos Aires (Argentina) in 2020. About 700 oral presentations were listened on the virtual conferences’ platforms, with thirteen special sessions and ten invited lectures, and a Panel on Climate Neutrality in Cities. The series of SDEWES Conferences aims at providing an international excellent networking platform for scientists and researchers involved in cross-cutting sustainable solutions about the fields of sustainable development of energy, water, and environment systems, with a focus on their integration and impact on environment, economy and social perspectives. In this framework, the VSI addresses modern issues and several crucial topics for fostering the energy transition and meeting the sustainable development targets, such as renewable technologies for zero-energy buildings and communities, emerging technologies and tools for the design of buildings and energy systems, alternatives for fossil fuels, and policies and regulations challenges and opportunities to tackle climate change and make progress towards a net zero energy economy. The discussion of the VSI deals with available technologies and measures, as well as on concepts and ideas for sustainable technologies which require further fundamental research and development. This underlines the commitment of SDEWES platform to meet the aims of Energy Reports to disseminate knowledge towards the sustainable development goals, supporting the fundamental shift in the way energy is produced and consumed, as well as modern buildings and cities must be designed and operated to be safe, resilient, sustainable and just in the long term.
